text: Standard 1: Students engage in the research process.

children.text: Planning Research
Choose questions and ideas related to a topic of study
Choose a research topic
Formulate questions related to a topic of study
Choose a research topic
List questions related to a topic of study
Select a research topic in a specific area of a study
Generate questions about a research topic
Develop a plan for researching a topic in a specific area of study
Organize a research topic or issue in a specific area of study using a research strategy
Generate connections between issues, texts, and topics of interest
Plan and use a research strategy
Pose relevant research questions
Generate and evaluate questions relevant to research topic
Use questions to narrow research topic
Organizing Information
Use developmentally appropriate reference tools to gather information e.g., picture dictionary, ABC chart, nonfiction books
Locate and gather information from a variety of print and technological resources
Use a variety of reference tools to access information i.e., tables of contents, dictionaries, and Internet
Presenting Information
Share items and/or information related to a topic
Report on a topic orally or in written format
Evaluation
Use self-assessment tools to evaluatepresentation e.g., checklist, pictorial (smiley/sad face)
Use self-assessment tools to evaluate presentation e.g., checklist, rubric, pictorial
Accessing Information
Use relevant resource materials to access information e.g., dictionaries, encyclopedias, videos, interviews, cassette recordings, Internet
Use relevant resource materials to access information e.g., dictionaries, encyclopedias, newspapers, magazines, videos, interview, cassette recordings, Internet
Use relevant resource materials to access information e.g., dictionaries, encyclopedias, newspapers, magazines, videos, interviews, cassette recordings, electronic databases, Internet
Use sources that are appropriate for the research purpose
Use a variety of sources, such as computer catalogs, magazines, and newspapers, to access information
Use a variety of primary and/or secondary sources to access information i.e., computer catalogs, magazines, newspapers, and primary sources
Know ways to effectively search electronic databases e.g., defining key terms and using limiters to focus a search
Gather reliable information to support a thesis
Evaluate and incorporate information from primary sources e.g., interviews and surveys
Evaluating Research Information
Identify accurate information related to a selected research topic or project
Use criteria to evaluate the accuracy of information e.g., factual vs. fictional text
Use criteria to evaluate the accuracy of information e.g., factual vs. fictional text, persuasive vs. informational
Differentiate between accurate and inaccurate information
Question the accuracy and relevance of information
Evaluate sources that present different perspectives e.g., by identifying sources of bias and distinguishing between primary and secondary sources
Cross-reference information
Evaluate relevancy of information
Use relevant information
Evaluate reliability, validity, comprehensiveness, author's bias, and author's expertise
Verify the quality, accuracy, and usefulness of information
Organizing Research Information
Use note-taking strategies to organize information
Develop and record information gathered e.g., reports, brochures, posters
Use note-taking strategies to organize information
Compose basic research reports or presentations
Use note-taking strategies to organize information that would include paraphrasing, summarizing, and identifying main concepts in information sources
Create charts, outlines, and graphs to organize and record information in a simple format from a variety of sources
Use information from several sources
Organize research information
Present research findings, including information and evidence from a variety of sources
Arrange sources in bibliographical format
Organize information from a variety of sources e.g., chronological
Summarize information
Identify and avoid plagiarism
Use primary and secondary sources
Use graphic organizer
Synthesize information in a logical sequence
Use quotations effectively
Defend research paper or project
Presentation and Evaluation
Assess research process and presentation based on certain criteria discussed through conferences with peers and/or teachers
Evaluate a research process and presentation using a rubric
Assess research process and presentation using information discussed in peer and/or teacher conferences
Evaluate a research process and presentation using a rubric based on certain criteria
Assess research process and presentation by conferencing with peers and/or teacher
Evaluate a research process and presentation using a rubric based on set criteria
Presentation
Write a research report
Write a research report using a thesis statement
Write a research report using a thesis
Write research papers and presentations using a thesis and organized information
Write a research paper
Present research information e.g., informative speech, Computer-assisted presentation, video presentation
Evaluating the Research Process
Assess research process
Evaluate a research product using a rubric
Evaluate the research process and develop strategies for improving it e.g., correct use of research format, accuracy of research, organization of information and use of sources
Evaluate the research process and apply strategies to a variety of writing purposes e.g., correct use of research format, accuracy of research, organization of information and use of sources
Evaluate the Research
Evaluate the research process
Evaluate a research product using a rubric
Evaluate the research process
Evaluate a research product using a rubric
Research Planning
Choose a broad topic, state the problem or question
Formulate a preliminary thesis statement
Form questions to focus research
Research topics independently using appropriate sources
Plan a research strategy
Determine purpose e.g., inform, persuade
Develop a research question
Organizing and Presenting Research Information
Use information from multiple sources when presenting research findings to defined audiences
Organize information from a variety of sources into a unified whole
Use a style sheet, such as MLA or APA, for citing primary and secondary sources
Paraphrase information
Use note cards
Develop an outline

text: Standard 2: Students engage in the reading process.

children.text: Phonological/Phonemic Awareness
Identify and manipulate individual phonemes (sounds) in a one syllable word (distinguishing initial and final consonant sounds and vowel sounds) /h/-/a/-/t/
Blend individual phonemes to make a one syllable word
Separate a one syllable word into its parts, onset and rime
Identify and create rhyming words
Know that words make up sentences and syllables make up words
Identify and manipulate individual sounds in words
Isolate and say the first, medial, or last sound in a word
Break or separate a word into parts – onset and rime
Identify and create rhymes
Literary/Informational Genres
Recognize a variety of genres i.e., fiction, nonfiction, fairy tales, poetry, and nursery rhymes
Identify the elements of a fiction text i.e., character, setting, events, and ending
Demonstrate book handling knowledge i.e., locate front of book, beginning and end of sentence and story
Demonstrate early reading behaviors i.e., oneto- one match, directionality, locating letters and words, upper and lowercase letters, periods, and question marks, using authentic texts
Differentiate between fiction and non-fiction text features
Recognize various types of nonfiction books i.e., newspapers, magazines, picture dictionaries, and other developmentally appropriate reference materials
Read a variety of genres i.e., fiction, folk tales, poetry, and nonfiction-informational
Explain elements of a story i.e., characters, events, setting, and ending
Read a variety of genres i.e., fiction including realistic, fantasy, folktales, and nonfiction including informational, biographies, and autobiographies
Describe the elements of a fiction text i.e., setting, characters, events, problem, and resolution/solution
Describe the features of a non-fiction text i.e., table of contents, index, topic headings, boldfaced words, and glossary
Phonics/Word Recognition
Recognize the relationship between letters and their sounds
State sounds for all letters in isolation
Know that letters go together to make words
Use knowledge of phonics to decode words
Identify and name upper and lower case letters
Apply knowledge of letter/sound relationship when reading
Use knowledge of phonics to decode words
Apply knowledge of letter/sound relationships when reading, including consonant blend and long and short vowel patterns
Use knowledge of phonics to decode words with a variety of spelling patterns
Comprehension/Reading Strategies for Meaning
Make and confirm/disconfirm predictions about what will happen in a story
Recall/retell information in sequence
State text-to-self connection
Make and confirm predictions about what will happen in a story
Recall/retell details/events in sequence
Make text-to-self and text-to-text connections
Use strategies to monitor comprehension e.g., reread, check picture, think about the story to determine what makes sense
Locate the main idea and identify supporting details of a text
Read a variety of vocabulary embedded in authentic text
Demonstrate fluency, reading in meaningful phrases: clear, at an appropriate rate, with expression and accuracy
Make and confirm/disconfirm predictions about what will happen in longer stories with increasingly complex plots
Recall/retell details/events in sequence
Relate text-to-self, text-to-text, and text-to-world connections
Use strategies to monitor comprehension e.g., reread, read on, check the picture, think about the story to determine what would make sense and sound right.
Use strategies to improve comprehension e.g., summarize, fact and opinion, compare and contrast, inferences, drawing conclusions, questioning, clarify
Locate the main idea and identify supporting details of a text
Use meaning, syntax, and phonics clues to decode new words when reading
Read a variety of vocabulary embedded in authentic text
Demonstrate fluency, reading in meaningful phrases: clear, at an appropriate rate, with expression and accuracy
Purposes for Reading
Use reading to be informed and/or entertained with shared reading texts e.g., big books, charts, poems, guided reading books
Use reading to be informed and/or entertained
Use reading to be informed, persuaded, and entertained
Read for a variety of purposes, including to gain information, for enjoyment, and to form an opinion e.g., role-playing, journals, diaries
Reflect on and respond to texts from various genres and cultures
Use reading to be informed, entertained, and persuaded e.g., role-playing, journals, diaries
Reflect on and respond to texts from various genres and cultures
Use reading to be informed, entertained, and persuaded e.g., role-playing, journals, essays
Reflect on and respond to texts from various genres and cultures
Read to be informed, entertained, and persuaded
Read to develop life-long reading skills and habits
Read to be informed, entertained, and persuaded
Read to develop life-long reading skills and habits
Read for a variety of purposes to develop lifetime reading skills and habits, e.g., form personal recreation, to model forms of writing
Read for a variety of purposes and intents e.g., to become life-long readers, to model forms of writing
Read for a variety of purposes and intents e.g., to become life-long readers, to model forms of writing
Read for a variety of purposes and intents e.g., to become life-long readers, to model forms of writing
Read for a variety of purposes and intents e.g., to become life-long readers, to model forms of writing
Literary/Informational Genres and Elements
Identify the elements of a fiction text i.e., setting, characters, events, problem, and resolution/solution
Identify characteristics of expository text i.e., headings, subheadings, captions, graphics, tables, and conventions of print
Identify characteristics of multi-cultural texts from various genres i.e., realistic fiction, historical fiction, poetry, folktales, fantasy, fairy tales, plays, and non-fiction
Use glossaries, table of contents, and indexes to locate information
Read a variety of texts i.e., fiction, nonfiction, and multi-cultural
Compare and contrast characteristics of fiction i.e., historical fiction, realistic fiction, short stories, poetry, and tall tales
Compare and contrast texts i.e., fiction to fiction, fiction to nonfiction, and nonfiction to nonfiction
Determine the elements of a fiction text i.e., setting, characters, development, rising action, events, problems, and resolution/solution
Determine characteristics of non-fiction text i.e., headings, subheadings, captions, graphics, tables, and conventions of print
Read a variety of texts i.e., fiction, nonfiction, and multicultural
Analyze the elements of a fiction text i.e., setting, characters, events, problems, resolution/solution, and universal themes
Analyze characteristics of non-fiction text i.e., headings, subheadings, captions, graphics, tables, and conventions of print
Compare and contrast characteristics of a variety of fiction genres i.e., mysteries, poetry, legends, novels, historical fiction, science fiction, myths, plays, and fables
Compare and contrast characteristics of a variety of nonfiction genres i.e., biography, autobiography, memoir, informational articles, editorials, and essays
Word Recognition/Vocabulary
Use word recognition strategies to determine the meaning of unfamiliar words and make sense of text i.e., synonyms/antonyms, prefixes/suffixes, words with multiple meanings, and context clues
Use word reference aids to determine word meaning; e.g., dictionary, thesaurus, and glossary

Use word recognition strategies to determine the meaning of unfamiliar words and make sense of text i.e., synonyms/antonyms, homonyms, prefixes/suffixes, words with multiple meanings, and context clues
Use reference resources to determine word meaning i.e., dictionary, glossary, and thesaurus

Use word recognition strategies to determine the meaning of unfamiliar words and make sense of text i.e., synonyms/antonyms, homonyms, word origins, prefixes/suffixes, words with multiple meanings, and context clues
Use word reference resources to determine word meaning i.e., dictionary, thesaurus, and Greek/Latin root histories

Use word recognition skills and vocabulary building strategies to determine the meaning of unfamiliar words and make sense of text e.g., synonyms/antonyms, prefixes/suffixes, multiple meaning words, context clues, and word reference aids – dictionary, glossary, thesaurus, base words
Reading Strategies for Meaning

Use reading strategies to increase and monitor comprehension i.e., building background with connections, main idea/details, fact/opinion, predicting, inferring, questioning, synthesizing, summarizing, and visualizing/verbalizing
Demonstrate fluency, reading in meaningful phrases: clear, at an appropriate rate, with expression and accuracy

Use a variety of text comprehension strategies to improve and monitor understanding i.e., building background with connections, main idea/details, fact/opinion, predicting, inferring, questioning, synthesizing, summarizing, analyzing, and visualizing/verbalizing
Demonstrate fluency, reading in meaningful phrases: clear, at an appropriate rate, with expression and accuracy

Use a variety of text comprehension strategies to improve and monitor understanding i.e., building background, main idea/details, fact/opinion, predicting, questioning, synthesizing, inferring, summarizing, visualizing/verbalizing, and analyzing
Demonstrate fluency, reading in meaningful phrases: clear, at an appropriate rate, with expression and accuracy
Literary and Information Genres
Identify characteristics of a variety of fiction genres e.g., short stories, mysteries, poetry, fables, myths
Identify characteristics of a variety of nonfiction genres
Differentiate characteristics of fiction and nonfiction genres
Compare or contrast characteristics of fiction and nonfiction genres
Literary Elements and Techniques
Identify literary elements, including plot, setting, characters, conflict, resolution, dialogue, and flashback
Identify figurative language, including personification, simile, metaphor
Identify literary elements i.e., foreshadowing, point of view, plot development, protagonist, antagonist, and theme
Locate figurative language in literary texts i.e., personification, simile, metaphor, and hyperbole
Identify sound devices in literary texts i.e., alliteration, onomatopoeia, rhyme, repetition, and rhythm
Explain the relationships between literature and historical periods, cultures, and society
Identify theme, protagonist, antagonist, and dialect in literary texts
Identify figurative language in literary texts including personification, simile, metaphor, and hyperbole
Make connections between literature and historical period, culture, and society
Explain the uses of sound devices in literary texts, including alliteration, onomatopoeia, rhyme, repetition, and rhythm
Identify character, setting, plot, stanza, act, scene, chapter, verse, article, fiction, nonfiction, point of view
Analyze an author's use of literary techniques and devices i.e., mood, foreshadowing, flashbacks, dialogue, and poetic license
Identify universal themes
Explain ways in which the setting affects the development of a story
Analyze author's use of literary techniques and devices i.e., foreshadowing and flashbacks
Identify author's use of figurative language including allusion, imagery, and symbolism
Analyze literary elements i.e., character, setting, plot, stanza, act, scene, chapter, verse, article, fiction, nonfiction, and point of view
Analyze author's use of mood
Apply universal themes to real life situations
Analyze author's use of poetic license and dialogue
Evaluate literature based on social, cultural, and/or historical contexts
Interpret author's use of figurative language including allusion, imagery, and symbolism
Interpret author's use of syntax and word choice/diction
Critique literary merit of a work of literature
Reading Strategies for Interpreting Meaning of Texts
Use graphic organizers and summarizing to enhance comprehension
Use prior knowledge and experiences to aid text comprehension
Use graphic organizers, summarizing, paraphrasing, and vocabulary building strategies, including context clues, to enhance understanding and aid comprehension of the meaning of texts
Generate and revise predictions to aid comprehension and understanding of the meaning of texts
Use prior knowledge and experiences to aid text comprehension
Use prior knowledge and experiences to aid text comprehension
Use a variety of strategies to construct meaning from text e.g., vocabulary building strategies, skimming, paraphrasing, summarizing, brainstorming, discussing
Identify persuasive writing
Locate redundancies in written texts to clarify meaning
Demonstrate oral reading fluency
Access prior knowledge to interpret meaning
Identify techniques used in persuasive writing i.e., deductive reasoning and use of fact and opinion
Identify techniques used in persuasive writing including inductive reasoning and propaganda
Locate ambiguities in written text
Apply prior knowledge of content to interpret meaning of text
Identify techniques used in persuasive writing such as fallacies of logic, faulty reasoning, and manipulative language
Vocabulary

Use vocabulary building skills and strategies e.g., synonyms/antonyms, prefixes/suffixes, analogies, multiple meaning words context clues, word reference aids – dictionary, glossary, thesaurus, to determine the meaning of unfamiliar words and make sense of text

Use vocabulary building skills and strategies e.g., synonyms/antonyms, prefixes/suffixes, multiple meaning words context clues, word reference aids – dictionary, glossary, thesaurus, to determine the meaning of unfamiliar words and make sense of text
Build vocabulary e.g., Greek and Latin roots, dictionary information, content area terminology
Use decoding/encoding, connotation, and denotation
Build vocabulary by reading a variety of gradelevel texts and applying new vocabulary
Use etymology to define words
Use technical language/jargon to decipher meaning
Informational Genres
Differentiate between a variety of nonfiction genres i.e., newspapers, magazines, electronic texts, biographies, reference materials, essays, and speeches
Summarize information from nonfiction genres
Analyze details, facts, and concepts from nonfiction genres
Critique details, facts, and concepts from nonfiction genres
Literary Genres
Identify characteristics of a variety of fiction genres i.e., novels, short stories, plays, and poetry
Identify the organizational features of fiction, drama, and poetry i.e., stanza, act, scene, chapter, verse, and article
Identify characteristics of literary forms and genres i.e., parody
Analyze religious writing, biographies, and political writings
Identify satire and allegory

text: Standard 3: Students engage in the writing process.

children.text: Prewriting
Identify audience and purposes for writing
Discuss ideas drawn from personal experience
Use developmentally appropriate tools for prewriting e.g., ABC chart, word walls, environmental print
Recognize a variety of purposes for writing, i.e., inform, entertain
Discuss and organize ideas drawn from prior knowledge using lists and webs
Write about familiar topics and ideas
Select a purpose for writing i.e., inform, entertain, or persuade
Gather and organize ideas drawn from a variety of sources e.g., prior knowledge, classroom/library references
Select a plan to organize thoughts before writing e.g., webbing, listing, other grade appropriate graphic organizers
Use a specific genre to match the purpose i.e., personal, expository, narrative, informational, journal writing
Select ideas and information to persuade, entertain, or inform using a specific genre of writing i.e., narrative, personal persuasive, traditional tale, poetry
State and organize prior knowledge and experience to produce a written text e.g., webbing, listing, gathering information, taking notes
Determine a message to inform, entertain, persuade a specific audience i.e., factual and personal persuasive, informational, poetry, fantasy
Demonstrate planning ideas to organize thoughts before writing e.g., webbing, listing, graphic organizers, taking notes
Plan writing for a specific audience and purpose to inform, entertain, or persuade i.e., memoir, factual, persuasive, poetry, narrative
Plan a written text using a variety of techniques e.g., webbing, listing, graphic organizers, taking notes to develop a topic or purpose
Use prewriting strategies e.g., brainstorming, graphic organizers, outlining
Use strategies to write for different audiences and purposes
Use strategies to write for different audiences and purposes e.g., informative, narrative, persuasive
Use free writing and journal writing to develop ideas for writing topics
Use language and format appropriate for intended audience and purpose
Develop a focus for composition e.g., a theme or unifying idea
Organize the ideas and details of a composition according to purpose
Use prewriting techniques to generate ideas
Organize the ideas and details of a composition according to purpose
Organize the ideas and details of a composition according to purpose
Organize the ideas and details of a composition according to purpose
Use variety of sources for supporting details
Drafting
Write from left to right
Use consonant sounds at beginnings and ends of words
Use some easy-to-hear vowels
Use spaces to separate words
Incorporate developmentally appropriate vocabulary in writing
Communicate meaning through drawing e.g., setting, characters
Match story with drawing
Read their own writing
Write frequently for a variety of purposes e.g., lists, journals, personal narratives
Compose at least three sentences about a single idea
Produce an organized piece with a beginning, middle, and end
Include supporting details in written work
Select descriptive language to add interesting details to a story
Write known words fluently
Write left to right across more than one line
Consistently use spacing to separate words
Spell many words conventionally
Incorporate vocabulary into writing
Write over time to produce longer, more complex texts
Identify and include the characteristics of different genres i.e., personal narrative, expository, informational, journal writing, letter writing
Use characteristics of different genres in writing i.e., narrative, expository, traditional tales, poetry
Use a variety of sentence structures i.e., simple and compound sentences
Organize and develop paragraphs with topic sentences, indentation, punctuation, and capitalization
Incorporate vocabulary in writing
Use characteristics of different genres of writing i.e., factual and personal persuasive, informational, poetry, fantasy
Organize and develop ideas by writing at least three paragraphs with topic sentences and supporting details
Use indentation, capitalization, and punctuation to write paragraphs
Incorporate vocabulary in writing
Compose writing that contains characteristics of a selected genre of writing i.e., memoir, factual persuasive, poetry, narrative
Organize and develop paragraphs using topic sentences, additional details, and supporting details in writing at least 5 paragraphs
Use proper paragraph form that includes smooth transitions between paragraphs
Incorporate vocabulary in writing
Use prewriting strategies to create draft
Incorporate grade-level appropriate vocabulary in writing
Use prewriting strategies to create a draft emphasizing details
Incorporate grade-level appropriate vocabulary in writing
Use prewriting product to create a first draft emphasizing details and referencing sources
Incorporate grade-level appropriate vocabulary in writing
Use organizational patterns e.g., introduction, body, conclusion or exposition/body/resolution
Elaborate ideas through word choice and description using grade-level vocabulary
Organize and write compositions for self and family
Use supporting details
Elaborate ideas through word choice and description using grade-level vocabulary
Organize and write compositions for school and peers
Use a variety of supporting details
Elaborate ideas through word choice and description using grade-level vocabulary
Organize and write compositions for town, city, and state
Use a variety of supporting details
Elaborate ideas through word choice and description using grade-level vocabulary
Organize and write compositions for nation and world
Publication/Presentation
Share published work with peers, teachers, and family members
Share published piece with peers, teachers, and family members
Evaluate writing process/product using a variety of assessment tools e.g., checklist, rubric
Share final copy with peers, teachers, and/or family members
Evaluate writing process/product using a variety of assessment tools e.g., checklist, rubric
Share final copy with peers, teachers, and/or family members
Share final copy with peers, teachers, and/or family members
Evaluate writing process/product using a variety of assessment tools e.g., checklist, rubric, conferences
Share final copy with peers, teachers, and/or family members
Evaluate writing process using a variety of assessment tools e.g., checklist, rubric, conferences
Incorporate visual aids into written work
Incorporate visual aids in publications
Incorporate a variety of visual aids in publications
Use computer technology to present written work
Use technology e.g., publishing software and graphic programs, to present written work
Revising
Reread written work to check for meaning, ideas, word choice, and organization
Check written work for meaning and syntax
Analyze written work for ideas, word choice, and organization
Review organization for elaboration, description, and syntax to improve the meaning and focus of a written text based on audience feedback
Review and monitor a written piece for organization, elaboration, description, clarity, and syntax to improve fluency and meaning
Revise written text based on feedback from peers and/or teacher conferences
Review and monitor organization of a topic in a written piece for elaboration, description, clarity, and syntax
Use feedback and multiple drafts to clarify language and purpose of the written text
Editing
Reread written work to check for spelling of known words and punctuation e.g., periods, question marks, exclamation points
Choose grade-level appropriate tools for writing i.e., dictionary, thesaurus, word wall, and environmental print
Use proofreading marks to edit written work for conventions i.e., punctuation, spelling, capitalization
Select grade appropriate tools for writing i.e., dictionary, thesaurus, word wall, classroom/library texts
Use proofreading marks to edit written text for capitalization, punctuation, spelling, sentence structure, grammar, and paragraph indentation
Use reference tools to edit writing i.e., dictionary, thesaurus, word wall, classroom library, word processor
Use proofreading marks to edit written text for capitalization, punctuation, spelling, sentence structure, paragraph indentation
Use reference tools to edit writing e.g., dictionary, thesaurus, word wall, classroom library, word processor
Use proofreading marks to edit written text for capitalization, punctuation, spelling, sentence structure, grammar, paragraph indentation
Use reference tools for writing e.g., dictionary, thesaurus, word wall, classroom library, word processor
Final Draft
Compose written text that demonstrates understanding of purpose and audience
Compose written text that demonstrates understanding of purpose and audience using a specific genre of writing i.e., narrative, personal persuasive, traditional tale, poetry
Compose written text that demonstrates understanding of purpose and audience using a specific genre of writing i.e., fantasy, factual and personal persuasive, poetry, informational
Compose written text that demonstrates understanding of purpose and audience using a specific genre of writing i.e., memoir, factual, persuasive poetry, narrative
Informative Writing
Produce informative writing e.g., researchbased report, instructions
Produce research-based writing e.g., news article, book reports, essay
Compose informative writing, e.g., research, biographies, autobiographies, news articles, interviews
Write expository texts e.g., essays, directions, and letters
Write expository texts including research papers
Write business or other formal documents, including resumes, scholarship letters, and letters of inquiry or complaint
Narritive Writing
Produce narrative writing e.g., short story, descriptive play, poetry
Produce narrative writing e.g., short story, poetry, drama
Write short stories that include story elements e.g., dialogue, action, physical description, background description, character development
Persuasive Writing
Produce persuasive writing e.g., opinion, essay, business letter
Produce persuasive writing e.g., business letter, essays, opinions
Produce persuasive writing e.g., editorials, essays, business letters, opinions
Develop a composition detailing an opinion
Defend a personal opinion using facts as support
Gather information supporting multiple sides of an issue

Write persuasive compositions, including structuring arguments logically, using rhetorical devices, defending positions with evidence, and addressing readers' concerns and biases e.g., editorials, critical reviews
Revising and Editing
Use criteria to evaluate own and others' writing e.g., stay on topic, organization, effective details, clarity of message, word choice, sentence fluency
Use feedback and multiple drafts to clarify language and intent
Edit for grammar, mechanics, usage, spelling
Use criteria to evaluate own and others' writing
Use feedback and multiple drafts to revise text for specific purposes e.g., clarity of ideas, organization, word choice, fluency
Edit for grammar, mechanics, usage, and spelling
Use criteria to evaluate own and others' writing
Use feedback and multiple drafts to revise text for specific purposes, e.g., clarity of ideas, organization, word choice, fluency
Edit for grammar, mechanics, usage, and spelling
Edit and revise compositions for proper mechanics and grammar, syntax, diction, and order
Arrange paragraphs in a logical progression
Edit and revise compositions with attention to content
Edit and revise compositions for consistent point of view
Use knowledge of sentence structure and sentence construction to edit and revise text
Use sentence reduction techniques to revise and edit compositions
Edit and revise compositions for standard writing conventions and transitional devices
Edit and revise compositions for standard writing conventions and appropriate tone
Edit and revise compositions for unity, coherence, clarity, and fluency
Edit and revise compositions with an awareness of parallel structures and proper verb tense and agreement
Edit and revise compositions for the use of proper clausal and phrasal patterns
Literary/Narritive Writing
Write descriptive and narrative compositions e.g., journals, personal letters, biographies, short stories, autobiographical sketches, oneact plays, and poetry
Literary Elements and Techniques
Use techniques of characterization in compositions e.g., description, dialogue, interior monologue
Use language appropriate to the format of the composition
Use precise language to describe people, places, and things
Use a specific point of view in compositions
Use figurative language in writing
Use techniques to convey an individual voice and style e.g., tone, syntax, diction, figurative language
Publishing
Incorporate visual aids (e.g., graphs, tables, and pictures) into written work to enhance meaning

text: Standard 4: Students engage in the speaking and listening process.

children.text: Verbal and Nonverbal Communication
Use developmentally appropriate speaking vocabulary, including words that describe people, places, things, locations, and actions
Actively listen to the speaker
Follow one and two step directions
Use developmentally-appropriate speaking vocabulary
Actively listen to the speaker
Follow two and three step directions
Use grade-appropriate speaking vocabulary
Actively listen to the speaker
Follow multiple step directions
Use appropriate speaking vocabulary
Use pitch, volume, and tone appropriate to the speaking situation
Use nonverbal communication skills such as gestures and eye contact
Demonstrate appropriate speaking vocabulary
Use pitch, volume, and tone appropriate to the speaking situation
Use body language, such as posture or the use of gestures, as a form of communication
Demonstrate appropriate speaking vocabulary
Use tone, emotion, verbal and nonverbal messages, facts and opinions effectively in oral presentations
Speak with purpose using delivery techniques appropriate for different audiences to inform, demonstrate, entertain, or persuade
Use appropriate volume and eye contact when speaking
Use volume, eye contact, rate, and pronunciation effectively in oral presentations
Use volume, eye contact, rate, pronunciation, and articulation effectively in oral presentations
Use visual aids effectively in oral presentations
Use notes and manuscripts to make oral presentations
Use appropriate body language in oral presentations
Use tone, inflection, pitch, and emphasis effectively in oral presentations
Conversation, Group Discussion, and Oral Presentation
Respond to peers in conversations
Take turns speaking in conversations
Formulate and respond appropriately to questions
Stay on topic while speaking
Take turns speaking in conversation
Formulate and respond appropriately to questions
Take turns speaking in conversation
Stay on topic while speaking
Participate as an active listener and speaker in any group discussion
Participate as an active listener and speaker in group discussions
Participate as an active listener and speaker in group discussions
Participate as an active listener and speaker in group discussions
Summarize key ideas of a speaker
Incorporate research into presentations
Construct questions in response to a speaker
Speak to entertain an audience e.g., story telling
Speak for different purposes e.g., group discussions, research presentations and demonstrations
Engage in a group discussion
Use critical listening skills i.e., reflection
Formulate questions in response to a verbal message
Adapt to a variety of speaking and listening situations such as formal presentations, oral interpretations, and group discussions
Analyze the audience and adjust message and wording to suit the audience while speaking
Use critical listening responses, such as refutation and commentary, to critique the accuracy of messages
Use oral composition techniques to perform speeches such as memorized speeches, impromptu and extemporaneous, persuasive/argumentative, and expository speeches
Planning for an Audience/Purpose
Organize information and ideas for an oral presentation to inform, demonstrate, entertain, or persuade i.e., narrative, personal persuasive, poetry
Organize oral presentations to inform, demonstrate, entertain, or persuade from an organized plan i.e., factual and personal persuasive, informational, poetry
Develop a presentation to inform, demonstrate, persuade, or entertain i.e., factual and personal persuasive, informational, poetry
Organize an oral presentation to inform, demonstrate, entertain, or persuade from an organized plan i.e., memoir, factual persuasive, poetry, narrative
Make informative presentations that outline and explain the key ideas of the topic
Use supporting materials for topic development e.g., research, personal experience, literature, interview, fact, opinion
Speak with a purpose using delivery techniques appropriate for different audiences to inform, demonstrate, entertain, or persuade
Use supporting materials for topic development e.g., research, personal experience, literature, interview
Incorporate literature in presentations, such as book reports
Speak with a purpose using delivery techniques appropriate for different audiences to inform, demonstrate, entertain, or persuade
Use supporting materials for topic development e.g., research, personal experience, literature, interview
Speak with a purpose using delivery techniques appropriate for different audiences to inform, demonstrate, entertain, or persuade
Use supporting materials for topic development e.g., research, personal experience, literature, interview
Analyze the audience and adjust message and wording to suit purpose
Analyze the audience and adjust message and wording to suit the purpose
Analyze the audience and adjust message and wording to suit the purpose
Evaluate audience based on social characteristics, e.g., religion, culture, and gender
Media Genres
Identify existing and developing media i.e., books, newspapers, television, computer programs
Identify existing and developing media i.e., radio, film, electronic sources
Identify existing and developing media
Use appropriate media genres for a variety of reading and writing purposes
Recognize the purposes of common types of media e.g., books, magazines, newspapers, television, electronic sources
Recognize existing and developing media
Recognize characteristics of common types of media e.g., books, magazines, newspapers, cartoons, radio, television, films, electronic sources
Recognize existing and developing media
Describe characteristics of common types of media e.g., books, magazines, newspapers, cartoons, radio, television, films, electronic sources
Describe existing and developing media
Compare and contrast characteristics of common types of media e.g., books, magazines, newspapers, cartoons, radio, television, films, electronic sources
Identify existing and developing media
Identify existing and developing media
Identify existing and developing media
Identify existing and developing media
Identify existing and developing media
Identify existing and developing media
Identify existing and developing media
Interpreting Media
Analyze the main idea and supporting details of a media message such as an advertisement
Describe the main characters, the setting, and the sequence of events in media content
Describe elements in media to establish meaning i.e., main ideas, supporting details, fact and opinion
Analyze media content for meaning i.e., main idea, supporting details, fact and opinion, propaganda, persuasion
Describe media production techniques and formats e.g., images and symbols, basic propaganda and persuasion, poster, slide show, billboards, brochures, and newsletters
Evaluate media content meaning i.e., important details, supporting details, propaganda and persuasion, sequence/timelines
Demonstrate media production techniques and formats e.g., images and symbols, basic propaganda and persuasion, slide show, billboards, brochures, newsletters
Identify the point of view of a media message
Identify bias in media messages
Define plagiarism and its consequences
Assess the relevancy and accuracy of information in media messages
Locate examples of freedom of expression in media messages
Define plagiarism and its consequences
Describe the role of the media in influencing and shaping public opinion
Show how media messages influence people in various ways e.g., comprehensiveness, appeal to emotions, attitudes and behaviors, authenticity, stereotyping
Define plagiarism and its consequences
Define copyright
Compare and contrast a written work and a media version
Evaluate the portrayal of ethnicity and lifestyles in media messages
Analyze media messages
Evaluate how coverage of the same events differs depending on the media type i.e., radio, television, and newspaper report of the same product or situation
Evaluate the accuracy of details in media messages
Evaluate the impact of media messages on daily life and politics
Evaluate instances of gender equity and political correctness in media messages
Evaluate media messages in their historical and/or cultural contexts and intended audience
Examine advanced media techniques, e.g., music and sound, camera angles, lighting, and aesthetic effects
Using Media for a Purpose
Construct different samples of media genres to inform and entertain an audience i.e., posters, newsletters, brochures
Evaluate media products of peers and self using a rubric
Construct samples of different media genres to inform, entertain, advertise, or persuade an audience
Evaluate media products produced by peers and self using a rubric
Produce samples of different media genres to inform, entertain, advertise, or persuade i.e., memoir, factual, persuasive, poetry, narrative
Use technology according to the district's appropriate use policy
Construct media messages e.g., slide shows, brochures, newsletters, commercials, advertisements
Construct media messages e.g., slide shows, brochures, news articles, commercials, advertisements
Access media (e.g., television, film, music, electronic databases, videos, DVDs, comics, visual and performing arts, newspapers, and periodicals) for a variety of purposes
Construct media messages e.g., editorials, news articles, commentaries, web sites, commercials, advertisements
Access media (e.g., television, film, music, electronic databases, videos, DVDs, comics, visual and performing arts, newspapers, and periodicals) for a variety of purposes
Use media (e.g., television, film, music, electronic databases, videos, DVDs, comics, visual and performing arts, newspapers, and periodicals) for a variety of purposes
Apply media (e.g., television, film, music, electronic databases, videos, DVDs, comics, visual and performing arts, newspapers, and periodicals) for a variety of purposes
Create a media project for a purpose

text: Standard 6: Students understand and use principles of language.

children.text: Language Conventions/Mechanics
Use sentences to convey a message
Use conventions of punctuation, i.e., period
Use pre-phonemic knowledge, letter sounds, knowledge of letter names, and commonly used words to spell independently
Use sentences to convey a message
Use developmentally-appropriate parts of speech i.e., proper and common nouns, singular and plural nouns, pronouns, and verbs
Use developmentally-appropriate capitalization i.e., proper nouns, beginning of sentences, titles
Use developmentally-appropriate conventions of punctuation i.e., period, comma, question mark, exclamation marks
Use developmentally-appropriate principles of spelling i.e., inventive spelling, commonly used words in writing
Use sentences to convey a message
Use parts of speech i.e., proper and common nouns, pronouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs
Recognize the subject and predicate of a sentence
Use capitalization i.e., proper nouns, beginning of sentences, titles
Use conventions of punctuation i.e., period, question mark, exclamation marks, commas, quotation marks
Use principles of spelling
Use parts of speech i.e., noun, verb, pronoun, adjective, adverb, prepositions, conjunctions
Use subjects and predicates in simple and compound sentences
Use verb tenses i.e., past, present, future
Use capitalization i.e., proper nouns, titles of books, magazines
Use conventions of punctuation i.e., ending punctuation, commas-in a series, with a conjunction, dates, city and state, greeting and closing of a letter, direct quotations, titles of books
Use principles of spelling e.g., double final consonant following short vowel, contractions, homophones
Use parts of speech i.e., regular and irregular verbs, adverbs, prepositions, coordinating conjunctions
Use subjects and predicates in simple and compound sentences
Use appropriate verb tenses
Use capitalization e.g., proper nouns, titles of books, magazines, newspapers, musical compositions

Use conventions of punctuation i.e., ending punctuation, commas – with a conjunction and contractions, apostrophes in the possessive, underlining, quotation marks, italics for titles of documents, parentheses
Use principles of spelling e.g., double final consonant following short vowel, roots, suffixes, prefixes
Use parts of speech i.e., noun, verb, adjective, adverb, prepositions, conjunctions, interjections
Use subjects and predicates in simple, compound, and complex sentences
Use conventions of grammar related to parts of speech, including verb tenses, modifiers, and pronouns
Use capitalization e.g., proper nouns, titles of books, magazines, special events, the first word in quotations when appropriate
Use conventions of punctuation i.e., ending punctuation, apostrophes in the possessive case, colon to introduce a list, use of semicolons to connect independent clauses
Use principles of spelling e.g., double final consonant following short vowel, Greek/Latin roots
Use grade-appropriate conventions of sentence structure i.e., simple, compound sentences, fragments, run-ons and declarative, interrogative, imperative, exclamatory
Use grade-appropriate conventions of grammar; i.e., eight parts of speech and simple and perfect tense

Use grade-appropriate mechanics and usage i.e., Capitalization: I, Proper Nouns, Proper Adjectives, and in sentences; Punctuation; end marks, quotation marks in dialogue, comma in a compound sentence, items in series, apostrophe, Usage: homonyms, spelling strategies for grade appropriate conventions of spelling

Use grade-appropriate conventions of grammar i.e., capitalization: dialogue, title of people and things; punctuation: commas, quotation marks, apostrophes, colons/business letters and in time, underlining/italicizing; usage: double negatives
Use sentence structure i.e., simple, compound, complex
Use grade-appropriate mechanics and usage i.e., capitalization
Use varied sentence structure i.e., simple, compound, complex, and inverted order
Use conventions of grammar related to parts of speech; i.e., verbs progressive tense, complements

Use grade-appropriate mechanics and usage i.e., capitalization: publications and in letters; punctuation: commas, semi colons, colons, quotation marks, underlining, hyphens, apostrophes; usage: misplaced modifiers
Identify conventions of grammar related to sentence structure i.e., sentence reduction, parallel structure, elliptical clauses, conjunctions, clausal and phrasal patterns
Use conventions of grammar related to parts of speech i.e., verb tense and agreement
Use conventions of punctuation
Use conventions of grammar related to sentence structure i.e., sentence reduction, parallel structure, elliptical clauses, conjunctions, clausal and phrasal patterns
Use conventions of grammar, usage, and punctuation to edit and revise
Use conventions of grammar, usage, and punctuation to edit and revise
Figurative Language
Use and interpret similes, metaphors, onomatopoeia and alliteration in oral and written messages
Use and interpret the meaning of similes, metaphors, alliteration, onomatopoeia, and idioms
Use and interpret similes, metaphors, alliterations, idioms, onomatopoeia, and personification
Identify and use similes, metaphors, idioms, alliteration, personification, and onomatopoeia
Literary Elements and Techniques
Use figurative language i.e., simile, metaphor, alliteration, personification, onomatopoeia, and hyperbole
Use figurative language including simile, metaphor, alliteration, personification, onomatopoeia, hyperbole, and point of view
Identify idiomatic language and figurative language i.e., allusion, analogy, hyperbole, irony, personification, oxymoron, paradox
Identify the use of sound patterns in language i.e., alliteration, assonance, consonance
Interpret symbolism
Analyze figurative language i.e., allusion, analogy, hyperbole, irony, personification, oxymoron, paradox
Interpret the use of sound patterns in language i.e., alliteration, assonance, consonance
Apply the use of sound patterns in language i.e., alliteration, assonance, consonance
Identify the use of language in different literary forms i.e., satire and parody
Apply figurative language i.e., allusion, analogy, hyperbole, irony, personification, oxymoron, paradox
Interpret the use of language in different literary forms i.e., satire, parody
Identify allegory
Langauge Context
Identify social differences in language e.g., the use of slang, cliché, formal and informal styles
Identify cultural and regional differences in language use e.g., different dialects and language diversity
Locate examples of professional uses of language including jargon and formal styles
Locate cultural differences in language i.e., colloquialisms, regional and ethnic dialects, indigenous vocabulary
Identify gender perspectives in language i.e., biased language
Critique cultural differences in language e.g., colloquialisms, regional and ethnic dialects, indigenous vocabulary
Critique gender perspectives in language i.e., biased language
Identify emotionally charged language
